captions.text:
I say, is it too
much to ask for both?

With that in mind,
I humbly present
the crown jewel

Of stark industries'
freedom line.

It's the first
missile system

To incorporate
our proprietary
repulsor technology.

They say the best weapon
is one you never have to fire.
I respectfully disagree.

I prefer the weapon
you only have to fire once.

That's how dad did it.
That's how america does it.

And it's worked out
pretty well so far.
Find an excuse

To let one of these
off the chain,
and I personally guarantee you

The bad guys won't even want
to come out of their caves.

For your consideration,
the jericho.

I'll be throwing
one of these in

With every purchase
of 500 million or more.
To peace!

<i>Tony.</i>
<i>Obie, what are you doing up?</i>

It went great.
Looks like it's gonna be
an early christmas.

<i>Hey! Way to go, my boy!</i>
<i>I'll see you tomorrow, yeah?</i>

Why aren't you wearing
those pajamas I got you?
<i>Good night, tony.</i>
(sighs)

The "hum-drum-vee"
is back there.
Nice job.
See you back at base.
<i>(back in black</i> playing)

title: Iron Man (2/9) Movie CLIP - The Jericho (2008) HD

nukes if he wanted, but he doesn't be cause it's not yet necessary.

comments.author: MonolithMZK

comments.text:

 "I'm done arguing a point that I know I'm right on, and you should quit

comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
The small encampment is an example, and I'm done arguing a point that I 
know I'm right on, and you should quit while you are ahead. Generally when 
everyone disagrees with you, you are wrong, but whatever. You'll delete my 
comment anyways because if you see something even remotely against you you 
have to delete it before people see.
comments.author: MonolithMZK

comments.text:
+MonolithMZK "If a small encampment is what you are shooting to eliminate, 
the Jericho would only have to be fired once. If you threw a grenade at a 
spider, you would only be throwing, you guessed it, one grenade."

Grasping at straws much? By your retarded "logic", any weapon could be 
considered "a weapon you only have to fire once", a grenade, a gun, even a 
drop of water, if your aim is to kill an ant.

Why this obsession with "small encampments?" Read much? We have had 
non-nuclear weapons that could destroy an entire encampment for ages now. 
Since when is "missiles that can destroy a small encampment" anything new 
or impressive? What exactly is your point? That Tony Stark's statement 
about the weapon is nothing but pointless hyperbole? Hello, that's *my* 
point.

"And contrary to what you may believe, WMDs are not a 
one-shot-destroy-everything kind of weapon."

When did I say that? WMD's power lies not only in its immediate 
destruction, which in itself is extreme, it also in its decades-long 
fallout, and most importantly, the potential escalation into a global 
extinction event. None of these apply to Tony Stark's joke of a weapon, so 
tell me this: why is Stark running around like a clown boasting a weapon 
that's a hundred times weaker than shit we had since the 50s, and more 
importantly, why are you running your mouth like a retard trying to defend 
his ass?
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+haitianxu
Correction, I misread the last bit of your response, so lop off the 
"nuclear war posterboy" bit at the end of mine.
comments.author: MonolithMZK

comments.text:
Obviously my post went over your head, again you arent thinking of scale, 
and you are getting very hostile in a conversation that doesnt warrant it. 
If a small encampment is what you are shooting to eliminate, the Jericho 
would only have to be fired once. If you threw a grenade at a spider, you 
would only be throwing, you guessed it, one grenade. And contrary to what 
you may believe, WMDs are not a one-shot-destroy-everything kind of weapon. 
They aren't as destructive as you would like to think they are. Yeah, 
symbolically, if you launch a WMD at anything, it generally creates fear 
from fighting back against something like that, but once again, scale. If 
you fired a Jericho at that small encampment and another encampment heard 
the destructive power, they might fuck off. So, therefore, you only fired 
it once, and it was in the symbolic meaning you were presumably shooting 
for. Im not trying to say you are entirely wrong man, Im just trying to get 
you too think about scale. I get that you want to be the poster boy for 
nuclear war and say the nukes are a cure-all, but thats just not the way it 
works.
comments.author: MonolithMZK

comments.text:
What was that, troll? I didn't read any of the garbage you posted before I 
flushed it down the toilet. Care to post again?
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+Barbara Romanowski <---butthurt troll post deleted.

Do you know that YouTube auto filtered your garbage? Yeah, that's how bad

You see me deleting any other posts in my thread? No. If you're here for an

Last chance before I ban your butthurt ass.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+Barbara Romanowski <----so this butthurt troll posted a long ass troll 
post that was auto-filtered by YouTube. I've restored & deleted that 
garbage. Nobody is going to bother with your long ass troll, try to do a 
better job next time.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+MonolithMZK"when in reality, its a replacement for short range missiles 
that are meant for exactly what the Jericho is also meant for: Taking out 
small forces or encampments."

Except Tony Stark completely disagrees with you. He referred to the Jericho 
as "the weapon you *only have to fire once*"

A powerful short range missile meant for taking out small forces or 
encampments is *not a weapon you only have to fire once*, but a WMD is.

A grenade is *not a weapon you only have to fire once*, but a WMD is.

It seems my point went completely over your head, as my entire criticism is 
on the ridiculous "only have to fire once" statement.

Either Jericho is comparable to a WMD, or Tony Stark is full of bullshit 
hyperbole. Which one shall it be?
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+haitianxu
You are right, but you are more wrong than you are right. Are WMDs a one 
shot wonder? Yeah, they are, but you dont use them on every little thing. 
You aren't thinking of scale. You are under the impression that they would 
be using the Jericho to overthrow an entire country, as a substitute for 
WMDs, when in reality, its a replacement for short range missiles that are 
meant for exactly what the Jericho is also meant for: Taking out small 
forces or encampments. You dont use WMDs for that, similar to how you 
wouldn't use a hand grenade to kill a spider in your house.
comments.author: MonolithMZK

comments.text:
+Barbara Romanowski "Firstly, are you on meth? If you want to use ad 
hominem, then shut the hell up, because that's like admitting you're too 
stupid to continue a discourse. Calm down."

That's a good point. Your ad hominem post is deleted. You're clearly mad as 
hell, my advice for you would be wipe the foams from your mouth and try 
talking like a civilized adult or STFU. Any 5-year-old insults will be 
deleted. This is my thread, deal with it or GTFO.
comments.author: haitianxu

comments.text:
+Barbara Romanowski No it's not. Do you even know anything about human 
history? The US deployed 2 nukes in actual combat in the 40s, and the 
destructive power of them were so much that the entire world is still 
afraid of it till this day, 70+ years later. That is precisely what Tony 
refers to as "the weapon you only have to fire once".

Say US goes to war with China, and US has Tony Stark's missiles. You think 
China would surrender after the US fires these missiles once? Are you 
delusional?

speaking as a screenwriter, if a scene is improved, we don't typically go 
back and type it into the finished script once the scene is completed. 
There is zero point in doing so. However, perhaps this scene was improvised 
during a rehearsal or table read, thus giving the screenwriter enough to 
time to write it down and type it into the script before production 
commenced.

comments.author: zackhanscom

comments.text:
The idea of multiple independent warheads breaking from a single launch 
vehicle dates back to the 70's with the Minuteman 3 MIRV. Conventional 
weapons with similar techniques have been around since the early 2000's if 
not earlier. One missile I know of contains over a hundred anti-tank 
weapons in one missile, meaning a single bombing run can destroy an entire 
armoured regiment with a fire and forget missile.

Japan has always had one thing that they somewhat live by, Pride and 
culture. Their pride led them to attack pearl harbour, their pride led them 
to fight to the death across all the war, their culture and history 
demanded that they fight to the death everywhere they fight, their pride 
led the war hawks in their government to continue the war as long as they 
did, plus you add in America was worried that soviets were going to invade 
and America wanting to intimidate them and the rest is history.

comments.text:
I was thinking about this for a while...Why didn't U.S drop the bomb of on 
the coast of Japan. No lives are lost and Japan would've saw the 
destructive power of the bomb. We could've stopped supplies from getting 
into the country as well. 140,000 people (not soldiers) died there. Japan 
was going to fall regardless, there was no point in dropping the bomb 
except a successful test on live human targets.
comments.author: Major Gutierrez

comments.text:
One of the reasons (among others, of course including the fact that it was 
almost untouched by bombs and would prove to be a good way to see how much 
damage it would do) Hiroshima was chosen was because 40,000 military 
personnel were stationed in the city, and because they had military bases 
there.
comments.author: Assassin0021

comments.text:
Yeah and I understand your point (most of it is true). Although I don't 
think any of us can say what the Japanese people truly wanted. I think I 
would've been slightly more okay with it if we would've dropped it on 
military personnel (and i'm not even okay with that) just like they did in 
pearl harbor but no, they dropped it on regular people that had nothing to 
do with the war. Like I said I agree that it lessened the casualties but 
that was just not the right move in my opinion.
comments.author: Major Gutierrez

comments.text:
In fact, even after the bomb was dropped on Nagasaki and the Emperor 
accepted unconditional surrender, there was an attempt at a coup by his 
advisers who still didn't want to surrender. Japan was engaging in total 
war, and thus it received total war in return. And I entirely understand 
about the people, though [note this is from what I've read on the subject] 
the people themselves were defiant. Those who lived through the atomic 
bombing did wish to surrender after seeing the horror of it.
comments.author: Assassin0021
